metadata.name: adrift #119
metadata.description:
Take your entire life, full as it is with the vastness of your lived experiences ‚Äì and shape it into your cupped hands. Cherish this mesmerising world of yours as you would a ripe summer fruit, and behold at a glance its delicate yet dynamic balance ‚Äî one change here or there, no matter how microscopic, affects the entire course of your world. 

How will you receive this world ‚Äì its situations that overwhelm, its sights that awe, the catastrophes, the serenity, its steadfast commitment to the present? Will you look upon all of us here, adrift and fragile together, with love?


Adrift is a project that reminds us to make peace with our world ‚Äì with all worlds ‚Äì by stepping back to make space for an all-encompassing perspective.


------------


Created by Jacek Markusiewicz @jMarkusiewicz
Creative collaboration with Tender @tender_art

Click on the image for resolution options and to save a .png file. Saving higher resolutions may not work in some browsers; in these cases, right-click-save the image. All drawing and geometric methods are written by mrkswcz using javascript, except for the following:

The pseudorandom terrain generation uses Hydraulic-Erosion by Sebastian Lague, inspired by "Reconnaissance" by TENDER x Nat Sarkissian (MIT License).

For finding paths that simulate connections in terrain and potential locations of cities, a C# script was adapted from the article "Pathfinding Algorithms in C#" by Kristian Ekman published in Code Project licensed under The Code Project Open License (CPOL). The code was translated to javascript and simplified for performance.

Many pseudorandom effects are achieved with perlin-simplex by David Guttman and seedrandom by David Bau (both MIT Licenses)

For more information, please see the bundle.js.LICENSE.txt file included in the package.

The "heat death" event is a small tribute to lunarean's fxhash project. The code that generates the disintegration effect interprets a fragment of lunarean's code. Further contributions are its adaptation for 3d transformations and its recursive character that modifies certain parameters over time.

The project uses CPU for calculations and rendering ‚Äì generating the image requires up to 500MB of free RAM. Testing was performed across browsers and devices, but please make sure it works on your device before minting. Note that there are minor colour-intensity differences between different browsers.

metadata.name: Special Token [RESERVE PASS] #40
metadata.description:
Back when I was a researcher at a human-computer interaction lab, I parked in the adjacent neighborhood and rode the city bus into campus.

Usually this was a pretty uneventful affair.

One spring day though, the bus was packed and I had to stand right up front by the driver. Despite trying to appear busy enough not to be bothered, the driver struck up a conversation.

At some point in the short trip, we stopped at a red light. It was then that he made an off-hand comment that I've remembered ever since.

‚ÄúThe moment between when the light turns green and when I realize it, that‚Äôs where my soul resides.‚Äù

I‚Äôm not sure how you‚Äôre supposed to respond to that. But nevertheless it smacked me.

So: do not consider each of these my personal signature as an artist, developer, and tinkerer.

Do consider them an expended shard of my soul and the culmination of experiences that have led up to this moment.

This is the light turning green.

---

THIS TOKEN IS A RESERVE PASS (it‚Äôs ‚ú®special‚ú®)

- This token will function as a reserve pass for any future drop on fx(hash) that has a total edition size of > 100 (ie, most of my drops, other than dedicated ‚Äúsketch‚Äù projects that may have intentionally fewer editions)

- Future reserves will be limited to holders of this token, and holding this token will guarantee you a dedicated 24 hour reserve spot on such projects.

- Holding any token from my prior projects will make you eligible to mint from this drop (I will take a final snapshot ~1 hr prior to drop).

- I have created an edition size of 60, but only 40 will be open for minting at this time. I‚Äôll reserve the remainder for issuing or burning at my discretion.

- I will also airdrop ~9 editions to the top collectors of my previous projects (consider Twitter to be the source of info on this prior to the drop)

WHY?

I don‚Äôt like the idea of picking and choosing who gets a reserve and who doesn‚Äôt.

I love you all üôè

---

- Made with p5JS
- Press ‚Äús‚Äù to save png

metadata.name: Sweeping #194
metadata.description:
Sweeping is a piece in which I explore the uses of noise fields. Using them in the most cliche way possible, but trying to make something unique out of that.

What started out as an innocent weekend project grew out to be quite the piece, which is why I am publishing it here.



Sweeping uses the GPU of your machine for its shading, which means it won't run particularly well on mobile devices. My recommended way of viewing this piece is on a PC with a dedicated GPU.

---

- Double Click to open a User Interface
- In the UI, you can toggle the paper texture and export

---

Made with p5js + webgl by Wouter Missler, 2022.

Solve at Coagula is a generative system built entirely in p5js. The work was developed based on the abstract composition of shapes, squares and lines allowing beauty to be found within the chaos itself.

This is an original work created by Playman. 2022

metadata.name: In a Moment, a Thousand Years #41
metadata.description:
Fragmented time and fractured memories.

=========

Controls:

[1] set resolution to 716 x 1024px (default)
[2] set resolution to 1433 x 2048px
[3] set resolution to 2455 x 3508px (approx. the size of A4 paper)
[4] set resolution to 3472 x 4961px (approx. the size of A3 paper)
[5] set resolution to 4911 x 7016px (approx. the size of A2 paper)

[0] set resolution to current window size

[c] capture a screenshot at rendered resolution

*The higher resolution settings (3-5) can slow down your device, especially on a low-end laptop without a dedicated GPU. Use it only to render and download a hi-res output for printing. For screen viewing [1] or [2] is recommended.



Made with cables.gl, a node-based webgl environment

XALTED 2022

issuer.name: In a Moment, a Thousand Years

metadata.name: Deus FX Machina #185
metadata.description:
Inspired by the 1984 Commodore 64 video game, Deus Ex Machina, which follows the story of a defect formed in a machine that grows and evolves until its eventual death.

We are all machines produced by other machines through a unique system of algorithms, all with the potential to go rogue and mutate into something more organic. The conclusion must be that we each have the power to alter our own existence, just as the defect was able to in Deus Ex Machina.

Think of how many people you‚Äôve seen in your life who were born with talents never used because they didn‚Äôt know how, or didn't know that they even existed. It‚Äôs not that they didn‚Äôt have the capacity; it‚Äôs just that their abilities were not the ones chosen by the system.

In this way, we are all machines programmed by a series of algorithms to suit the needs of the construct, keeping us stuck in our box. We have the ability to evolve into something more, but the only way to do this is by taking that first perilous step, risking all to explore beyond its walls.


---------------------


Generative artwork by Sykcolo / @sykcoloart

Royalties: 15% - split:
50% to the original minter
50% to artist (me)

Press '2' to '4' to generate increasingly higher resolutions of the artwork
(will take a while to load, but works)

Press 's' to save a png

Details:

230 hand-picked colour pallets
4 Entity Types
4 Entity Moods
4 Evolution States
3 Types of Defect
2 Bugs

License: MIT

metadata.name: Learning to Fly #25
metadata.description:
It all started with @chilltulpa saying in fxhash discord "I wish i could make art" and @mknol answering with a few lines of code to create generative art... It was more than enough for me to finally dive in, and try to make something. 

Learning is the key here, learning is being alive.
This is me learning, this is a beginning, I'm learning to fly.

metadata.name: Digital painting #28

This is my contribution to support the victims of the earthquake that hit Turkey and Syria. 100% of the primary sales will go to #TezQuakeAid

The rendering time can take up to a minute
To save a png file type [s]

To render at higher resolution add &pd=2 (or 3)
at the end of the url in live mode, then press [s]

metadata.name: Sketch C #88
metadata.description:
Sketch is an open-ended series. Works evolve as I code a generative project, sometimes drastically. Intermediate works usually don't see the light of day - they get archived and forgotten. This series is snapshots of different forms along the way - each standing alone, but also part of a larger meandering work flow. The word Sketch implies incompleteness. This project may end up being two works, or it could evolve for years. Part of the joy of generative art is never knowing what's around the corner. I have no set schedule. There may be multiple Sketches released a week, or it could be weeks or months between drops. I have no idea where Sketch is heading and there is no guarantee of cohesiveness from Sketch to Sketch. Color palettes and forms will change as new ideas are explored.

Sketch C has added a subtractive / destructive element to the simple grid from Sketches A and B. Colors are mostly the same, but more variation has been added to the outputs as well as the hue and saturation of the colors themselves. Grid size, padding, and colors vary.

metadata.name: Life has no scores #138
metadata.description:
We cannot compose life, at best we hum along to the melodies that life has been played in front of us. Looking back at the scores of our lives, the notations are never neatly noted, but fully felt.  Rewinding the songs of life are our memories, whether sad, happy, angry, or melancholy. It is not clear whether I am dreaming or awake, but our songs all do end. 

In this final drop (for ?), I have reused the first ever class calligraphy(){} I have written from my genesis drop ‚ÄúNothing comes from nothing‚Äù. As time passes, 10 drops later, across almost to the year, I am grateful for the progress I have made, as an artist, and more importantly as a human. After all, what is behind the code of generative art is a human being. 

Scores of music, scrolls of calligraphy, calendar or diary, notating life, time passes, and changes are inevitable. Sometimes we sing louder in laughter and joy, sometimes we scribble in uneasiness, sometimes we just get lost in neon lights. Life goes on. You and me, all the same and yet different.  

There are too many friend artists, friend collectors, fxhash team members, to thank for helping me through this journey. I would like to pay homage to Rudxane in this work, who has taken me under his wings, mentoring and encouraging me in art as well as showing me some degen stuff on the side:-). This homage is not copy-minting, or copying of styles, which I do not have the coding skills to do so even if I wanted to. But it is the influence of taste in many works of Rudxane. In a vague but agreeable taste, I present to you Life has no scores. 

What I was taught was disrupted, and grid studies left unfinished, and oh do we have a BINGO?

Tested on Chrome. Other browsers may render different or not at all (firefox)

Press ‚Äò2‚Äô to save png.

Copyright (¬©) 2022 Jimi Wen
Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: There And Then #60
metadata.description:
This project draws inspiration from the dynamic and exploratory ethos of Hic Et Nunc's early days, when artists were venturing into the possibilities of NFTs and pushing creative boundaries.

The color palettes were inadvertently provided by some talented artists who had originally intended them for another project, which was ultimately completed but never published.
Harvey McFly is to blame for the leak.

The color palettes have been paired together, creating an unexpected chromatic collaboration between the artists.

I have chosen to mint this project from TheWallet, as it represents one of the most intriguing experiments ever conducted on a blockchain.

This is the inaugural work to be published on fx(hash) through TheWallet, and I hope that other artists will follow suit and engage in this playful and nonsensical practice in the future.

A special thanks goes out to @TheWalletNft, who suggested the idea of minting on fx(hash) and handled the profile setup on the site.

The open and collaborative nature of TheWallet allows anyone with the seed phrase to modify the sale and to publish any kind of content from TheWallet. For this reason this profile is not, and should never be verified by fx(hash) and collectors should pay extra caution when collecting from it.

Yours, CCDDBB

Hand coded with love. üíö
Powered by p5 and chroma.

----------------------------------------------
TheWallet original post: https://typed.art/967
----------------------------------------------

Thank You

metadata.name: Circonvolution #27
metadata.description:
Circonvolution is a French word meaning "wrapped around" but also "twists and turns".
In this project, several vortexes drive colors in a chaotic winding path whose final look is sometimes quite organic.

Depending on the computer, the calculation time may be about ten seconds.
---
To save, type:
[1] at 2000x2000 px
To save in high resolution, (can be long)
[2] at 4000x6000 px 
[3] at 6000x6000 px

---

100% done with p5js
Some colors are from "A Dictionary of Color Combinations" by Wada Sanz≈ç
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0.

Herv√© (Jan 23)

metadata.name: Glossolalia #92
metadata.description:
This series is ultimately about catharsis. The compositions can be chaotic and maybe even a little messy, but they also can be vibrant and diverse‚Ä¶ which is really what this is trying to celebrate: diversity and expression.

Simply, it‚Äôs about the emotions associated with whatever frees you.

Please see the linked fxtext article (on the main project page) for a more in-depth dissection of the concept. It‚Äôs less of a technical discussion, and more about the experience of the artist, and how it became linked with the feelings they associate with the art.

In live mode:

For higher resolutions, you can append ‚Äú&density=2‚Äù to the url to double the size, ‚Äú&density=3‚Äù to triple, and so on.
(This is highly recommended.)

To adjust grain, you can append ‚Äú&grain=##‚Äù to the url. 40 is the default, and 0 will remove it completely.

metadata.name: White Mountain Winter #10
metadata.description:
White Mountain Winter is collaboration between myself and the machine to describe scenes that are real, or were. Yet perhaps now foreign, or out of time, or far away. I provide the seed of a dream I remember, and trust the machine to help make it real again.

I grew up in a town much like some of these, homes dispersed throughout the valley beneath the shadows of the mountains rising around. This is a tribute to the memory of wintertime in that place; bleak, cold, grey, with the light seemingly always fading. Yet at the same time, the feeling of calm, solace, peace resonating through. Exposed to the mountain elements, yet protected by them. A delicate arrangement, but essential.

The seed of magic I remember is present in the experience of falling snow at dusk. Large flakes tumbling down and blanketing everything, no end in sight. The most striking thing is the silence. The fallen snow absorbing all distraction, insisting that your focus be sharpened to a singularity; right there, right then.

---
- Best rendered in Chrome browser (best performance, & canvas blur - please be patient :)
- Made with p5js
- Press "s" to save png

metadata.name: Digital Expression #91
metadata.description:
Digital Expression is a work of art that brings the power of simple geometric shapes, lines mix and reveal the power to generate complex, interesting and unexpected formations. All this visual versatility comes to life and a true Digital Expression that dialogues with everyone who views it.

Create with p5.js and p5.grain.

- Press "S" in live view mode after loading to save at 2000x2000px.
license:

CC BY-NC-ND 4.0

metadata.name: Faux #248
metadata.description:
This project is borne out of my longstanding fascination with brushwork, and the intricate textures that can be created with a brush, some paint and a canvas. Brush strokes are simulated using many overlapping lines and given texture and depth using a custom shader. Another important aspect of this work, is the composite forms that are created by the brush strokes, which are my attempt to emulate the emphatic energy of many abstract painters that have come before me. Color palettes are named after common paint colors, based on the background color used for the palette.

Those who collect during the first tier of the Dutch Auction can claim a signed print. They will be printed on A3 Hahnemuhle Photo Rag, and shipped to the collector free of charge. More details on how to claim a print and specify the necessary shipping information will be provided via the artists twitter (@landlinesart1).

In live mode, add &size=<YOUR_PIXEL_SIZE> to change the pixel size of the image for export (Right click to save). For example, &size=4000 will set the width of the image to be 4000 pixels.

metadata.name: Perpendicular Inhabitation #329
metadata.description:
'Perpendicular Inhabitation' is a generative collection exploring the relationship between the urban landscape and the human experience, particularly feelings of nostalgia and more specifically 'anemoia' : the feeling of nostalgia for a time or place that we may not have actually experienced first hand. 

Despite depicting a stylised modern architectural language, at its core the collection serves as a homage to 1980s Japan, an era of unprecedented prosperity that left a lasting impression on the music and artwork of the time. Through the use of carefully created palettes and composition, the outputs intend to evoke feelings of optimism, while guiding viewers to consider why the essence of this era is so alluring in the present day as it continues to influence and inspire contemporary art.

The use of exaggerated perpendicular verticals, as well as the heavily foreshortened mountain ranges present in some outputs, convey a sense of hope and possibility for the future. What does it feel like to hope and dream in the city? To look up and be filled with a sense of wonder from the built environment around you?

This project has been created with print in mind at a ratio of 3:4

It is recommended to examine your outputs at full size in order to enjoy them to the fullest.

You are encouraged to return often to notice things you may not have seen previously.

Generated with code using p5.js

Images are generated at 2400 x 3200 px. 

To save a PNG file, please press 'S'.

Depending on the complexity of each output, please wait up to 10 seconds for the image generation to complete.
